TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators, I feel very proud today because of the great honour you have bestowed upon me. In recognition of that honour I say that I am also very conscious of the responsibilities of the office of President. I assure this chamber that I will do my utmost in an earnest endeavour to conduct the affairs of this chamber with the same high standards as my predecessors. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am delighted that I should have the privilege of first calling you Mr President. On behalf of my Government, and I am sure of all honourable senators, I acknowledge you as the President of this chamber. We assure you of our full support and loyalty. We know that you bring to the office qualities of character, dignity, experience and merit that will do further honour to the Chair. Mr President, this chamber has a long, honourable and magnificent tradition, and that tradition has been added to year by year by the Presidents of the past. Your predecessor, himself a South Australian, added further lustre, as did those before him.

SPEECH.PARA: You have served long here. I have been proud to call you friend, as others have. I acknowledge also that I have been proud to know your wife, and she will bring to her high office with you a great dignity and charm. You have served in many capacities in senior roles-as Chairman of Committees, as Government Whip, and as Opposition Whip. You have a true sense of this chamber. You are, through your service in the past, a true parliamentarian. The highest tribute one can pay to a President in his objectivity is that he has a sense of parliament, and that he brings to his office that sense. You in your journey, with our full support and with our warmest congratulations, will add further strength to the tradition of this chamber. We wish you good fortune and success for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of the Opposition I would like to congratulate you on your success in the ballot just conducted. I suppose of all the things that can be regarded as success in politics, winning ballots is one of the highest. I must say that I have not studied you as closely as Senator Carrick, but I concur with all the nice things he said about you of which I have personal knowledge. On behalf of the Opposition I wish you every success in your role as President of this chamber. In our view and, I think, in the view of historians and your successors, your success or otherwise will be measured by the extent to which your deliberations and presidency of this chamber are touched by the wand of tolerance, firmness and complete impartiality. We hope that will be so and we wish you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of the Australian Democrats I warmly congratulate you on your success today in gaining the highest office in this Parliament. We congratulate you very sincerely. I am very pleased to say that I and all the members of my party voted for you.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, as far as I know all the members of my party voted for you. You are a friend of mine. You have been a friend of mine for, I think, 14 years, but that is not the reason I voted for you. Seriously, the reason we took the view that we should give you, a member of the Liberal Party, our support was in no way connected with the fact that you belong to a political party which happens to be in government. We feel very strongly that the Government is entirely separate from the presidency of this place. We believe that a member of the Liberal Party should be President because that party has the greatest number of members in this chamber. We will be adopting that same philosophy for the next ballot to be conducted in this chamber. I thought it would be fair to make that point at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it this new Senate is unique in Australian politics. It is the first Senate in which the balance of power is held by an independent political party. It will not be easy for you, Mr President. Without naming anybody, a few of us here are known to be rather controversial people and a hung Senate or a tied Senate could bring you a number of problem days and problem nights. We sincerely hope, with respect, that you will be fair and impartial in your treatment of Ministers and ordinary senators and, above all, that you will always act as the defender of senators' rights against the Executive which, over the years, has tried to intrude its hand into this place. In that regard we can do no more than ask you to follow the magnificent example set by your predecessor, whom we both admire.

At the risk of introducing a discordant note into these proceedings I want to say this to you: As a fair and a just man, you will be as disappointed as I am to learn that, for some incomprehensible reason, the Government has refused to grant any pair under any conditions to any senator belonging to the Australian Democrats or to Senator Harradine. Pairing is to be freely available to all senators of the Liberal Party, the National Country Party, which has fewer members in this place than the Australian Democrats, and the Australian Labor Party. Apart from being a rather quaint way to begin this session harmoniously and towards achieving an atmosphere in which consensus can be achieved, it is blatant discrimination against members of a party democratically elected to hold responsible office in this place. I mention it very briefly now, Mr President, in order to acquaint you with the difficult task that you have ahead; to acquaint you with some of the initial problems which many confront you in your new capacity as a result of decisions which have been made but which are not of your making. Apart from being unfair and discriminatory, the decision of the Government is against the spirit of democratic representation.

I shall illustrate what I mean. Let us assume that the Government introduces a Bill, as it did three years ago, breaking an election promise of maintaining six-monthly indexation of pensions. Let us further assume that one of the five Australian Democrat senators is very ill or absent from the chamber on compassionate grounds. That Bill would be passed by this Senate because that Australian Democrat senator, absent through illness, would not make up the numbers to tie the vote. In that situation the Government would have deliberately refused to grant either him or her a pair.

I make the point that that would be a gross and deliberate distortion of a vote in Her Majesty's Parliament. Every other honourable senator, except Senator Harradine and ourselves, would be granted a pair and leave of absence would be given for that vote. To complete the record, Mr President, when I discussed this matter with Senator Carrick this morning he stated that if I were prepared to limit our requests for a pair only to occasions when there is a death in one of our families or when one of us is ill, he would then consider taking that proposition to 'his people'. Mr President, you will understand in a flash why I flatly rejected that offer. All that Australian Democrat senators ask for is to have the same rights as other senators. We will not be regarded as people having second class rights in this place. I sincerely hope that the Government will look at this problem and present a reasonable solution to us by the end of this week. In conclusion, Mr President, we wish you well in the difficult task ahead of you.
Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The recess has not helped the mental retards on the other side of the House. I offer to you and your wife our congratulations and good wishes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I add my personal congratulations and those of my party, the National Country Party. The warmth of our congratulations and feelings for you as you take up your important task is not to be measured by the brevity of what I am about to say. I endorse those very true things which have been said of you by previous speakers here this afternoon. I am sure that your long experience in this place, your knowledge of procedures and perhaps above all your fairness and unquestioned integrity will be of great value to this chamber and to the institution of Parliament. I endorse the things that have been said about you and warmly congratulate you. I am glad that you, a distinguished South Australian, are following another distinguished South Australian in the office of President. I am sure that your contribution to this chamber will be a constructive contribution and will enable this chamber to be the sort of constructive and dignified place that it should be. I offer my congratulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as your adversary in the ballot which has just occurred, I welcome the opportunity of congratulating you on your election as the sixteenth President of the Senate. From the floor of the Senate, the task of President often appears to be an easy one. But, having sat in the President's chair on a temporary basis on a number of occasions, I can assure honourable senators that the task is not easy. The task that you have will be quite demanding. We must also remember that you, as President, will have a number of administrative and ceremonial duties associated with your office of President, and because of that the demands upon you will be even greater. I certainly wish you well, and I hope that your term of office will be not only demanding but also rewarding.

SPEECH.PARA: Those of us who came into the Senate between December 1975 and early this year have served in the Senate under one President only; so to serve under a new President will be a new experience for many of us. As far as I can recall, the previous President called me to order only once. I dare say, Mr President, that you may have to do that in the future, although there will not be a deliberate effort on my part to get you to do so. But there is one part of your predecessor's example that you will not be able to follow, in that when he called me to order I was delivering my maiden speech. Again, Mr President, I offer my congratulations and my good wishes for your term of office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of myself I congratulate you on your election to the presidency. One of the most important functions of the Senate and of individual senators is the expressive or representative function. The right of any honourable senator to speak in this chamber should not be dependent upon the whims of the Whips, and I expect the President of the Senate to uphold that right of individual senators. I expect that there will be a difficult time ahead. I note that on your election to the position of President of this place you are also the Chairman of the Senate Standing Orders Committee. One of the matters that have been referred to that Committee is the question whether a seconder is appropriate for any motion before this Parliament, that is, whether any honourable senator should have the opportunity to represent the viewpoints of those persons who have elected him to this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not been advised of the proposition relating to pairs, presumably because I have not yet asked for any; but I might just mention that the Legislative Council of Tasmania is composed mostly of independent members and there is no difficulty in arranging pairs. There are some very interesting ways in which members notify their intention of seeking a pair, but provided that that is made good within a certain time it is accepted by that Parliament.
Mr President, your duties will not be easy. They will depend on the good will of the Senate and the good will of individual senators. So far as I am concerned, you have my good will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, as I understand it, was born in Quorn, South Australia, but he is in fact a Tasmanian senator. Therefore, as a South Australian I would like to claim the privilege of welcoming the second South Australian President under whom I have had the privilege of being a member of this House and to say that I am sure that you, Mr President, will do at least as well as your distinguished predecessor. I add in passing that I had a few rather unpleasant moments around midday today when I thought perhaps something had come unstuck. When I returned to my office I discovered that a large box of envelopes which had been delivered to me was addressed to me and labelled 'President of the Senate'. I was not quite sure at that time whether someone was anticipating a coup or was having a trial run at prophecy. I can assure you, Mr President, that as far as I am concerned I hope it is the latter. I congratulate you. I am proud to work under you.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators, I express my very sincere thanks to all of those honourable senators who have been so kind to me in their remarks today and who have also wished me well as President of this chamber. I again assure the Senate that I appreciate that things will not at all times be easy in this chamber, as they have not always been easy in the past. Having said that, I again want to emphasise that I will conduct myself, I hope, in an earnest endeavour not only to be fair but also to be seen to be fair to all people in this place. I trust that with the co-operation of the other chairmen who occupy the chair and honourable senators we can perform the duties of this place at the standard and in the manner in which they have been conducted in the past.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators, again I thank you very much for your remarks and for your support, and also for the good wishes expressed to my wife, Margaret. I take this opportunity also to welcome from the chair all the new senators who have joined us today. I wish you well in your deliberations and your associations in this place. I trust that you will have a long, worthwhile and happy term as senators in this august chamber.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now proceed to elect a Chairman of Committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendment to the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick):

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the appointment of a Chairman of Committees be made, prior to the dispatch of any other business, after the Senate has determined any motion for the appointment of a second Deputy-President, or after the Leader of the Government in the Senate has informed the Senate that he will not move such a motion'.

I move that amendment by reason of the fact that, quite suddenly so far as I am concerned, there has emerged from the Government parties a proposition for the establishment of another position of Deputy President, that is, a Deputy President, Committees, as distinct from what, presumably, we are supposed to vote for in the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, that of Deputy President, Procedures. At present nothing in the Standing Orders states that the office for which we are required to elect an occupant at this time is that of Deputy President, Procedures. There have been reports of horse trading between the senior coalition partner, the Liberal Party of Australia, and the National Country Party in regard to positions of Deputy President. I find it hard to believe that the National Country Party would be engaged in any such horse trading having regard to the statements made by Mr Nixon about horse meat traders, namely, that he would throw the book at them.

I feel it is unfortunate that the Senate should be put in the position of having to decide who shall occupy one of the offices of Deputy President. In fact, the position of Deputy President or Chairman of Committees is not mentioned in the Constitution. Two objections are raised to my proposed amendment. The first is that the Senate should, and is bound to, elect a Deputy President or Chairman of Committees. The Constitution merely requires that we elect a President. Section 18 of the Constitution states that before or during any absence of the President, the Senate may choose a senator to perform his duties in his absence. That covers the situation where you, Mr President, are absent. Additionally, it is said by some that under the Standing Orders we must appoint a Deputy President. Standing Order 26 states that the Senate may appoint a Senator to be Chairman of Committees, who, unless otherwise determined, shall hold office until 30 June, and so on.

The second major objection posed is that a question arises as to who would be the Chairman of Committees during the Committee stage of any Bill. Mr President, Standing Orders 28A and 31A provide that you, sir, shall appoint a panel of not less than two senators to act as Temporary Chairmen of Committees; also that you may call on either to relieve you in the chair. So, in fact, there is no requirement that the Senate elect today a Deputy President, or Chairman of Committees. Neither the Constitution nor the Standing Orders contain a requirement that that should occur. In fact, precedent shows that on 13 occasions the Senate has not elected a Deputy President on the first day of sitting. Indeed, on one occasion, it did not proceed to such an election until three weeks after the commencement of the session.

In view of what I have outlined, it would be quite in order for the Senate to delay appointing a Deputy President who would, of course, be the Chairman of Committees. It must be understood by honourable senators that at present the Deputy President is paid an additional $6,500 and that, under the proposed 1981 review of remuneration, he will be paid almost an additional $8,000. I am not in a position to cast my vote for a Deputy President at this point unless I know how many Deputy Presidents we are to have and what are to be their functions. It is unfair of the Government to suggest that the Senate should now proceed to the election of a Deputy President without knowing how many such officers there are to be and what are to be their functions. Additionally, the Government will have to prove to the Senate that the proposed expenditure involved is warranted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I second the amendment moved by Senator Harradine. I have had a few discussions with him this afternoon and recognise his concern about the fact that two positions are being suggested at this stage. However, I can assure him that although we may sometimes use the quality of our representation to further a particular cause it is only on rather rare occasions that we do that, even though we are in the unique position of being able to do that. On this occasion I assure Senator Harradine that we plead not guilty to either horse trading or trading in horsemeat.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

That the present level of funding under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme is causing financial hardship to many Tasmanian families and jeopardizing the future tertiary studies of young Tasmanians.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are gravely concerned by the invasion of privacy caused by Government agents seizing patients' medical records:

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should-Legislate to protect the private and confidential nature of medical records from scrutiny except on the express and informed consent of the patient or an order from a presiding judge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised-that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing, therefore your petitioners urge that:
1. All pensions and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the National Average Weekly Male Earnings seasonally adjusted.
2. Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973. Re-introduction of Medibank in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

3. To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government inject $200 million into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not fulfilling its responsibility in ensuring an adequate standard of living for all Australians, which is causing untold hardship on relief agencies' limited resources, and require the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:
1. That the Commonwealth Government raise the level of all pensions and benefits at least to the poverty line.
2. That the Commonwealth Government reconsider its recent decisions in relation to the health system and cuts to Commonwealth activity.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert further poverty and suffering in our community by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PASSENGER FARES AND SERVICES TO AND FROM TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate on 11 June 1981 I lay on the table the report of the Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania. In accordance with the terms of the resolution, the Clerk authorised the printing and circulation of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the transcript of evidence, and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
When I moved to establish this inquiry, I said:

I trust that the Senate will support the establishment of a small select committee, to use the select committee procedure, to enable Tasmanians to find out what is the majority view about what will best serve Tasmania's interest as a State of the Commonwealth in linking it with the remainder of the Commonwealth. The Committee should be able to present a report which can identify to government, to the ANL and to the airlines what questions have been brought out as a result of a public inquiry . . .

The Committee had two fundamental aims in the inquiry: Firstly, to assemble information to produce and stimulate an informed debate in Tasmania and elsewhere on transport issues and, secondly, to examine those issues and make recommendations as appropriate.

Widespread concern has been expressed in Tasmania in recent years about interstate passenger transport, especially the cost of travelling, but little information has been available to produce an informed and coherent debate on the subject. The various inquiries into Tasmanian transport up to 1980 concentrated on freight, with scant attention being paid to passenger services. The Committee has included much background information in the report to try to rectify this deficiency. The second aim was an examination of both air and sea passenger transport issues. This included consideration of the effects on Tasmania of the report of the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares-the Holcroft report-and the Commonwealth Government's response to it. It was the work of another Senate committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Primary and Secondary Industry and Trade, whose 1971 report on 'Freight Rates on Australian National Shipping Services to and from Tasmania' started the process which led to the introduction of the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme. We hope that our report on passenger services will be the catalyst for an improved passenger transport service for Tasmania in the future.

Many suggestions were put to the Committee for reducing the cost of air fares, including compensation or subsidy schemes. The most comprehensive of these was submitted by the Tasmanian Government. Essentially, the scheme would allow Tasmanian residents to receive a 40 per cent reduction on their return economy air fares between Tasmania and Melbourne for journeys originating in Tasmania. The Committee did not support that recommendation. The 40 per cent reduction was assessed as the difference between the cost of travel by air and land-based modes of transport on the mainland over similar distances. In principle, it is an extension of the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme to cover passengers as well as freight. It was proposed that the benefits be limited to the residents of Tasmania.

On 1 April 1981, in response to the Holcroft report, the Commonwealth Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) announced changes to the national air fare formulae from which all Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines fares are calculated. The effect of this decision was to increase significantly fares on short-haul routes, such as those between Tasmania and Melbourne, and decrease fares on long-haul routes such as Melbourne to Perth. Cognisant of the effect which the full increase would have had on Tasmania, the Minister also announced that the Commonwealth would fund directly a 10 per cent subsidy on all routes operated by Ansett and TAA between Tasmania and Melbourne. The Government's decision very clearly acknowledged Tasmania's disadvantage in relation to interstate passenger travel.

The Committee believes, however, that a subsidy is not necessarily the answer to Tasmania's passenger transport problems. There is no guarantee that its real value will be maintained or even that a future government will not reduce or remove it as the cost of maintaining it grows. In the case of Tasmania, the value of the subsidy could also be eroded by changes in the relativities between fares on short-haul and long-haul routes arising from further changes to the air fare formulae. In addition, a subsidy does nothing to overcome other shortcomings in air services identified during the inquiry. The Committee believes that compensation schemes or subsidies should only be used if no other methods of overcoming the problems are available. The Committee therefore considered alternative proposals for providing cheaper and better air services for Tasmania. The Holcroft report identified the high fixed costs which apply to a national airline network operator. Evidence to the Committee indicated-I stress this point-that a regional operator with adequate loadings could operate profitably with fares at 70 per cent to 80 per cent of the national airfare formula.

The Committee therefore considered two alternative air service concepts for Hobart and Launceston. The first was the replacement of Ansett and TAA by a single regional operator. The second was the introduction on those routes of a regional operator in competition with Ansett and TAA. The information available to the Committee indicated that both concepts would result in cheaper and better services with a similar standard of jet aircraft to those proposed by Ansett and TAA. The Committee envisages the regional operator, being based in Tasmania, would provide the State with a significant new industry. Such an operator would also be in a position to take account of the needs of Tasmania without having to balance those needs with the needs of a national network.

Neither concept is free from obstacles. The substitution of a single operator for Ansett and TAA would require their voluntary withdrawal from the routes. The Commonwealth Government does not have the power to deny licences for interstate routes except on safety grounds. Although the third operator concept does not face this difficulty, it runs into conflict with the Government's current two-airline policy. This restricts operators on routes such as those between Melbourne and Hobart and Launceston to Ansett and TAA.

During the passage of the Airlines Agreement Bill through the Parliament earlier this year, the Government announced that it would establish an inquiry into deregulation of the airline industry to report within five years. If the Government accepts some form of deregulation, then there is the opportunity to introduce changes into the Tasmanian services. It would also be possible for Ansett, TAA and the Commonwealth Government to agree on changes to Tasmanian air services at any time if they so wished. The two concepts outlined by the Committee are therefore longer term, and not necessarily immediate, solutions to Tasmania's transport problems. In the meantime, the Committee believes that the Government should maintain the real value of the current 10 per cent subsidy on Tasmania to Melbourne routes. I emphasise that the Committee is saying that in the meantime, until some of its suggestions are taken forward, it recommends the maintenance of the existing subsidies.

In the north-west there was the feeling that Ansett and TAA had provided an adequate service, but that an upgraded service, preferably a jet service, was desirable. There was also concern expressed about the future of the service, because the airlines had not made any commitments beyond the life of the F27s on those routes. In fact, TAA announced last Wednesday that it would be handing over its north-west Tasmania services to East-West Airlines Ltd. With regard to the upgrading of services to the north-west, the Committee noted that within three or four years a new generation of fast, pressurised turbo-prop aircraft will be available. These aircraft could upgrade the present F27 services. However, because of the expressed desire for jet services, the Committee examined the justification and feasibility of jet services for the north-west. The Committee concluded for reasons outlined in the report that there is justification for jet services for the north-west. However, there are a number of factors to be considered as to the feasibility of introducing jet services.

Neither Devonport Airport nor Wynyard Airport is equipped to handle jet services at present. Both airports would need to be upgraded. To upgrade Devonport Airport to F28 standard would cost $2.9m and to DC9 or Boeing 737 standard, $5.5m. To bring Wynyard up to the standard for F28 aircraft would cost $4m and to the other standard, $6.5m. A prerequisite for the government upgrading of either airport would be its transfer from Commonwealth to local ownership under the Aerodrome Local Ownership Plan. To this end, the Marine Board of Devonport, in association with the transport company, IPEC, has been negotiating with the Department of Transport for more than three years on the transfer of the Devonport Airport to the Marine Board.

The Wynyard Municipal Council and other councils in the north-west and west coast areas of the State served by Wynyard Airport have recently been giving consideration to entering into negotiation with the Department of Transport for the transfer of the ownership of Wynyard Airport to a sub-regional committee. Under the Aerodrome Local Ownership Plan, the Commonwealth Government will upgrade the airport to a standard to meet what it considers to be present and future needs. It will also meet half of the cost of upgrading terminal buildings. From an operational point of view, the information available to the Committee indicates that there is currently only enough traffic for jet services to operate to one north-west airport and maintain an acceptable frequency of flights. If jet services were to be operated to both airports, frequencies would have to be reduced or a triangular service adopted, or the north-west services would have to be carried out in tandem with one or more mainland services.

The Committee believes that the introduction of jet services to the north-west is justified and feasible, subject to the aforementioned qualifications. The Committee supports their introduction. The Committee also examined the future of the north-west services. Last week TAA announced that it would relinquish its services to north-western Tasmania. This is in line with the gradual withdrawal by both Ansett and TAA from their F27 regional routes throughout Australia. I interpose for a moment to say that, if Press reports are to be accepted, there are indications that negotiations are taking place in relation to Queensland regional routes in respect of both TAA and Ansett, as well as arrangements for the transfer of some of the New South Wales routes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you trying to start a debate?

—No, I was just referring, without comment, to Press reports. The Committee believes that the replacement of both Ansett and TAA on the north-west routes by a regional operator would be in the best interests of the region. Regional operators normally offer advance purchase excursion fares and stand-by fares which Ansett and TAA do not offer on the north-west routes. A regional operator would also promote the north-west as a gateway to Tasmania. Proposals to operate a regional service to the north-west were received by the Committee from both East-West Airlines Ltd and IPEC. The Committee discussed both proposals in the report to illustrate various objectives or characteristics which the Committee believes a regional operator should display. I emphasise that the Committee does not wish to support or oppose any proposal from a prospective applicant for a route licence. This is the responsibility of the Department of Transport and the Commonwealth Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee examined air services to the Bass Strait islands. The Committee recommends a 20 per cent subsidy for air fares to and from Flinders Island and King Island to compensate residents of the Bass Strait islands for their total dependence on air travel. The shortfall in revenue to the airlines should be met by the Commonwealth. The Hobart-Christchurch air service, which began operating at the end of last year, was also examined by the Committee. Patronage of the service, up to April 1981, increased steadily. The number of forward bookings gave encouragement to the Committee about the future viability of the service. The Committee noted that it would be 12 months or more before the route would be included in overseas package tours and travel itineraries and so the ultimate success of the route would not be known for some time.

The Committee examined the current sea service, the need for its continuation, demand for it, and various options for replacing the Empress of Australia, which is due to be retired from the Bass Strait service later in the decade. The Committee believes that the Bass Strait sea passenger service is essential for Tasmania. Without it Tasmania would be dependent solely on air transport, which in recent times has been subject to serious industrial disruption. Apart from the disadvantage of depending so heavily on air transport, there is the question of equity. On the mainland of Australia a range of modes of transport is available to choose from including a very heavily subsidised rail network. It would be inequitable for the Commonwealth Government to reduce further Tasmania's restricted transport options particulary in light of the huge subsidies spent on surface transport on the mainland. The sea service also presents other advantages for Tasmania and Victoria, and for travellers, which are enumerated in the report. The Committee considered the extent of latent demand for the service. After examining the number of passengers carried in the last two decades, the Bureau of Transport Economics estimates of demand based on its econometric calculations, and other factors, the Committee estimated that current demand, if capacity were available, would be about 135,000 passengers per annum, growing to about 145,000 passengers per annum once the service is operational and is promoted.

The Committee gave careful consideration to a service to replace the Empress of Australia later this decade. A number of options had already been rejected as impractical by both the Australian National Line and the Bureau of Transport Economics, such as the jetfoil, hydrofoil, hovercraft and semi-submersible catamaran. The Committee received no further evidence to suggest a contrary view. The Committee also evaluated the two service types which the Bureau of Transport Economics used in its 1980 report. The first equated the current service and the second was a two-ship service, each ship making a return crossing every 24 hours between Burnie and Westernpoint Bay, carrying passengers and cars by day and freight by night. This service was similar to the service recommended by Commissioner Nimmo in 1976. The Bureau of Transport Economics found the first service to be uneconomic. That is supported by the losses which the Australian National Lines has incurred in operating the Empress of Australia in recent years. However, the Bureau of Transport Economics found that some of the options of the second service would be economic. The Committee scrutinised the factors and assumptions used by the Bureau of Transport Economics in formulating its econometric model and concluded that the extent--

TALK.START.PARA: —There is that word again.
—I will try it again in a minute.
—Why don't you incorporate your speech and be done with it?

—I have only a couple of pages to go. The Committee scrutinised the factors and assumptions used by the Bureau of Transport Economics in formulating its econometric model and concluded that the extent to which they had to be qualified rendered the results unreliable. There was sufficient evidence to suggest that the second Bureau of Transport Economics service may be neither economic nor practical. After close questioning of representatives of both the Bureau of Transport Economics and the Australian National Line, the Committee concluded that limitations in the terms of reference given to the Bureau of Transport Economics, the truncated duration of its inquiry and the lack of sufficient Australian National Line input contributed to the shortcomings in the Bureau of Transport Economics report.

SPEECH.PARA: The ANL told the Committee it was looking at a ship similar in type to the Empress of Australia but with a five-fold increase in freight capacity. This would have the effect of providing enough freight capacity to meet the needs of one northern Tasmanian port while providing a similar passenger capacity to that of the present ship. The ANL considered that the total operation would be an economic proposition. Although the Committee was attracted to the combined freight and passenger concept, it believed that a much greater passenger capacity should be catered for. Rather than try to design and build one large ship, the Committee preferred to see the construction of two passenger-freight ships, one with a capacity of 450 passengers, cars and freight sailing between Melbourne and Devonport and the other with a capacity of 200 passengers, cars and freight sailing between Melbourne and Burnie.

Because, in any event, between 1985 and 1990 the ANL has to replace the three Searoader freight ships which carry most of the freight between Northern Tasmania and the mainland, the Committee believes that there is logic in constructing two freight-passenger ships to meet the freight needs of the two northern Tasmanian ports, Burnie and Devonport, and to provide increased passenger capacity at the same time. A third ship at least would need to be constructed to meet the heavier freight requirements of Bell Bay which it is anticipated will maintain its position as the major freight port.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Thank you, Senator Grimes. The Committee noted the long history of concern about transport between Tasmania and the mainland. The very first committee established by the Senate was a committee inquiring into passenger fares and transport across Bass Strait and that was in 1901. The Committee believes that a facility ought to be available for examining problems which inevitably will arise in the future. The Committee believes that the inter-State Commission, which is contained in the Inter-State Commission Act 1975, has the functions and the capacity necessary to carry out this task. This Act has not yet been proclaimed. The Committee recommends that the Interstate Committee be established and authorised to examine Tasmanian transport problems in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I thank all the organisations and individuals who made a contribution to the inquiry. In particular, I thank the Tasmanian and Victorian Governments for their co-operation, and Ansett Airlines of Australia, Trans-Australia Airlines, ANL and the Commonwealth Department of Transport for supplying much additional information to the Committee, very often at short notice. I also thank my colleagues, Senator Grimes, Senator Tate, and Senator Townley, who I believe did what a number of people thought may not have been possible; that is, produced what I hope is a constructive, forward-looking report which is unanimous and which attempts to put forward a plan which can do away with subsidies and make the services suit the requirements of Victoria and Tasmania. In conclusion, I take the opportunity to thank the staff of the Senate Committee for their work in producing the report, notwithstanding some problems such as breakdowns of equipment of various sorts, including the word processor and the reproduction equipment, and a rolling strike in the office of the Government Printer. They did a very good job in getting out a report notwithstanding all those problems. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to refer in some detail to the report which I have had pleasure in placing before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to be associated with the presentation of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania. May I emphasise firstly that the Committee was very ably chaired by Senator Peter Rae, who in this area is well informed, able and indeed indefatigable. He was very considerably helped by Senators Grimes and Townley. My part in the preparation of the report was indeed very small, but that does not preclude me from seeking to share some of the honours now that it is before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The report deals with a most important matter. In the Australian federation Tasmania is unique. It is a State which is physically isolated from the mainland; yet it has very close social, economic, trading and commercial ties with it. Some 80,000 Tasmanians live on the mainland and wish to maintain their links with relatives and friends in Tasmania. I repeat: Our commercial and trading links are very largely with the mainland. My area of north-west Tasmania is oriented more to Melbourne than to the State capital of Hobart. But to reiterate the obvious, unless a person is one of the 111,000 sea passengers who cross to and fro between Tasmania and Melbourne every year on the Empress of Australia, to enjoy interstate travel he must take the most expensive form of transport in the Australian federation-air travel. More than a million passengers move to and fro between Tasmania and the mainland each year. When one considers that the population of Tasmania is only 400,000 or so, one is provided with some measure of the importance of this particular link. The situation is indeed unique and would allow one to mount a very sound argument for the Commonwealths voting moneys to help build an air and sea bridge between Tasmania and the mainland in the same way as it finances interstate land based links, whether by road or rail.

Rather than seek to pursue that old approach, the Committee has been concerned to look for national policy frameworks which would allow to develop such appropriate services by aircraft and ships, and such transport policy, as would permit to emerge a fare structure which would require the payment, by people who wished to travel between Tasmania and the mainland, of fares that would be as modest as it would be possible to achieve.

Thus, as Senator Peter Rae has pointed out, in relation to the main trunk routes, between Melbourne, Launceston and Hobart, the Committee proposes, as a preferred solution of the problem, that a regional operator based in Tasmania have the exclusive right to operate. By bringing in specialist aircraft and non-parallel scheduling and feeding efficiently into the national trunk-work on the mainland, one could provide a cheaper service-it has been estimated some 10 to 15 per cent cheaper-than is presently provided by the two major domestic airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a subsidised basis.

—Yes, even with the subsidy that is currently operating. With the current two-airline policy that is enshrined in legislation, and presuming that that policy is achieving overall national objectives which can lend themselves to Commonwealth support, there is an obligation on the Commonwealth-the possibility of the cheaper, more efficient regional operator solution having been debarred-to subsidise such air travel. It is only on the basis that the Commonwealth, for national reasons, is pursuing a less efficient policy in relation to Tasmanian air travel, that we say that the present 10 per cent subsidy is fair and equitable and seems to work very efficiently. But there is good reason for apprehension about the political will to sustain such subsidies. That is why the Committee has been concerned to move away from them.

SPEECH.PARA: That is demonstrated once again in the Committee's deliberations on a replacement for the Empress of Australia, which, I repeat, carries some 111,000 passengers each year between Melbourne and the great port of Devonport on the north-west coast of Tasmania. The Committee felt that there was good reason to suppose that there was a latent demand which was being suppressed because of an inefficient booking system and an inadequate capacity. Indeed, the Empress is at 84 per cent of its possible load factor throughout the year and at well over 95 per cent during the peak periods of travel. Also, we believe that with increased promotion sea travel would prove attractive to some 145,000 passengers travelling between Tasmania and the mainland each year.

On that basis it has been suggested that to try once again to move away from subsidies which Tasmanians do not want we should construct as a replacement for the Empress of Australia two vessels, one plying between Melbourne and Devonport and carrying 450 passengers on top of an enhanced cargo freight operation-some five times greater than that operating at present-and a similar vessel carrying about 200 passengers on top of a cargo freight service operating into Burnie. These well-promoted services would run on a daily basis with a night-time crossing to and fro between Melbourne and north-west Tasmania. We can see this as an economically viable solution as the carriage of so much freight will make the ships economically viable and do away with the need for the $2.5m subsidy which is currently provided from the Commonwealth Treasury. This picks up the general theme of the Committee that, where possible, the most efficient, commercial solution will be found to be compatible with a modest structure of fares and ought to be pursued as expeditiously as possible. If some other national objective fails to commend that course to the Federal Government, then and only then should a subsidy be paid from the Commonwealth Treasury.

Because of my interest in north-west Tasmania I will spend some moments on north-west air services. As to the upgrading of airports, it is the very strong recommendation of the Committee that both Devonport and Wynyard airports be upgraded to enable them to take jet services. This is not a mere unfounded assertion or claim by these regions. The Committee took pains to establish that by comparison with, for example, regional New South Wales where some eight airports are proposed to be upgraded to jet status and by looking at those airports in outback and regional Australia which already have such services, such as Mt Isa and so on, there is no doubt that the claims of Devonport and Wynyard are well-founded, each airport having well over 85,000 passenger movements a year, which is unique at such regional airports. The entrance of jet services to the north-west of Tasmania is well justified. Therefore, the upgrading of those airports, based on local ownership, is also justified. One looks forward with interest to tonight's Budget to see what appropriations will be made in that regard.

The communities and the sub-regions of the north-west of Tasmania are prepared to take on local ownership, to undertake the expenditure involved and to give support through their local councils and marine boards to the management of such airports. It is up to the Commonwealth Government to complement that endeavour portrayed in those projects fostered in the north-west of Tasmania. In any such upgrading it is essential that Devonport airport terminal building be completely rebuilt at the total expense of the Commonwealth Government. No cost sharing should be undertaken. The present terminal is a disgrace. Indeed, it was a Royal Australian Air Force training shed somewhere in the Launceston area during the Second World War which was transpDevonport. We have had to put up with this very inadequate facility at the tourist gateway to Tasmania ever since. It needs to be upgraded immediately.

We have been somewhat overtaken by events in the past week with Trans Australia Airlines announcing its withdrawal of Fokker Friendship services between the mainland and north-west Tasmania. The Committee took the view that unless TAA and Ansett Airlines of Australia upgraded their services they should be asked to withdraw in favour of a specialist regional operator such as that which is indeed replacing TAA, namely, East-West Airlines Ltd. There is no point lamenting the fact that TAA is going. One might express some disappointment at the manner in which it is leaving and the manner in which it dealt with some of its staff relations on the human level. Nevertheless, it is leaving. I believe that north-west Tasmania will want to make the best of the opportunity of having a specialist regional airline operating into Tasmania with appropriate aircraft, with therefore a lower flagfall because it would not be bearing national overheads, and with a real desire to promote north-west Tasmania as, as I have mentioned before, the tourist gateway to Tasmania.
