SPEECH.PARA: It is my privilege to outline to the Senate the Budget proposals of the Government.
1980-81 IN RETROSPECT
1980-81 was a year of solid growth and achievement for the Australian economy.

It was a year in which the benefits of this Government's economic policies not only became more apparent, but were widely enjoyed by the Australian people. Nothing illustrates this more than the fact that real wages rose by over 4 per cent in 1980-81-a gain that was shared by 140 000 extra people in employment.

It was a year in which the fight against inflation was seen more clearly than ever before, not as an end in itself, but as a means of achieving greater investment, more jobs and higher living standards for all Australians.
I say these things fully recognising that for those affected by the recent drought it was a year of adversity and, in many cases, real hardship.
Economic success was achieved across a broad front.
Production, employment, investment and consumer demand were not only stronger than a year earlier, but greater than thought likely at the time of the last Budget.
Australia's international reputation as a strong, reliable country in which to invest, was further enhanced.
Among the economic indicators, the area of greatest strength was undoubtedly business investment, which contributes so much to activity and employment and hence to rising living standards.
Even last year's optimistic Budget forecast of strong growth in this area clearly under-estimated the upsurge then in prospect.
During 1980-81, private business fixed investment grew by more than 20 per cent in real terms-the largest such growth for 30 years.
There could be no clearer proof of the extent to which confidence in the economic future of this country has returned.
Although the mining sector made a hefty contribution towards this investment growth, strong increases were recorded in manufacturing and other sectors.
Private dwelling investment continued to grow firmly, with a real increase of about 11 per cent.
There was also a strong lift in personal consumption expenditure of about 3 1/4 per cent in real terms.
Over the year to June 1981, Australia's inflation rate as measured by the Consumer Price Index was 8.8 per cent-almost 2 per cent below the rate a year earlier.
The outcome-again better than had been forecast in last year's Budget-was aided by a lower rate of increase in import prices flowing in part from the strong appreciation of the Australian dollar.
Although the margin narrowed, Australia's inflation rate remained below the average of OECD countries.
Business profits grew strongly last year but their further growth, so vital to continued investment and employment, is now being threatened by rising wage pressures.
Overall, gross domestic product increased by almost 3 per cent in 1980-81, with growth of 4 per cent in the non-farm sector being offset by the fall in farm product associated with the drought.

The sharp rise in non-farm activity was reflected in a strong rise in total employment, which increased by 2.6 per cent. This was enough to reduce overall unemployment to its lowest level for four years, well beyond our original expectations.
This brief summary of the Australian economy over the past year presents a picture of considerable success and progress.
It contrasts sharply with the general experience of other OECD countries where, in aggregate, there has been higher inflation and unemployment and slower growth.

I would, however, be less than frank if I did not also point to some areas of concern to the Government and to certain challenges which, if not effectively tackled by this Budget and policies more generally, could undermine the progress and success to which I have referred.
If a response to those challenges is put off to another day, they will be infinitely harder to resolve, the process of resolution more painful and the damage to our economic recovery all the greater.
In his Budget Speech a year ago, the Treasurer spoke of the threat then posed by excessive wage demands and industrial disputes.
Regrettably, the past year-and particularly the past few months-has seen the pressure for higher wages intensify.
If unchecked, this will not only lead to higher inflation but reverse the falling trend in unemployment and put at risk both invesment and employment growth.

It would be grossly unfair if excessive wage demands from those in employment were now to damage the prospects for further job creation just when we have begun to see real gains being made in reducing unemployment.
It is important that the abandonment of the wage indexation principles not be seen as having left a vacuum in this area.

In recent days Commonwealth and State Governments, as well as the ACTU and National Employers, have all pointed to the continued existence of workable conciliation and arbitration processes-which in some respects are more flexible than the indexation arrangements-to settle wage claims.
It is essential that all parties co-operate to make these processes work effectively.
Such an outcome would help to moderate excessive wage claims.
INTEREST RATES

No Government likes to see interest rates go up. This Government is acutely conscious of the effects of rising interest rates on all borrowers, especially home-buyers. We therefore regret the necessity for the further increases announced last week.
It is important for all of us to understand why interest rates have increased and what needs to be done to reverse this trend.
Interest rates have risen because the total demand for money in the community has exceeded its availability.
In such circumstances interest rate rises are unavoidable unless the Government were prepared to print as much money as was demanded. This it will not do because of the inflationary consequences.
It follows that if interest rates are to be brought down the growth in the total demand for money must be reduced.
This demand comes from a number of sources, including businesses and prospective home- buyers.
There are also demands from governments at all levels to finance their current activities and to refinance earlier deficits.

In recent years government borrowing demands have been reduced, due entirely to reductions in the Commonwealth Budget deficit. However, with strong private sector demand, this fall has not been sufficient to prevent a significant increase in the total demand for funds.
As a consequence, there has been upward pressure on interest rates.

If this pressure is to be eased in a way that does not damage private sector activity or add to inflation-outcomes that would reduce job opportunities and retard economic growth-it is imperative that the borrowing demands of all levels of government be further reduced.
The need for such action led to the Loan Council decisions in June to cut by about 4 per cent in real terms the total Commonwealth and State semi-government borrowing programs.

Clearly, however, this Budget must make a further and substantial contribution towards reducing government borrowing demands if the upward pressure on interest rates is to be eased and indeed reversed. I can think of no cause more important to Australian families at present.
We have therefore decided that this year we must go as far as possible towards eliminating the Commonwealth's Budget deficit.
THE BUDGET OUTCOME FOR 1980-81
Last year's Budget generated the first domestic surplus since 1973-74; in the outcome, both it and the overall deficit were about $400 million better than had been expected.

Outlays were within 1 per cent of the Budget estimate. Receipts, however, were 2 per cent-$683 million-greater than estimated, mainly reflecting larger than expected income tax collections from both individuals and companies.

Receipts from the crude oil levy were $35 million less than estimated, with the effects of industrial disputes on production from Bass Strait more than offsetting the higher import parity price from 1 January 1981.

For two years in a row now, large reductions in the Commonwealth Budget deficit-$1,444 million in 1979-80 and $906 million in 1980-81-have been accompanied by strong growth in private sector economic activity.
THE BUDGET STRATEGY
In putting together this year's Budget the Government had to ensure that it would meet a possible resurgence of inflation head on.
A less firm Budget, while easier to prepare, would carry with it a real risk of a fresh outbreak of inflation, thereby undermining the prospects for sustained economic growth in the years ahead.

In particular, the uncertainty and loss of international competitiveness that would result from a new inflationary spiral would deter the production and investment essential to the creation of additional jobs and higher real incomes.
We have therefore opted for a Budget which gives priority to containing and reducing inflation and sustaining private sector growth.
It is a Budget which reduces the overall deficit by almost $1,000 million.
This decisive move towards overall balance symbolises the Government's determination to play safe with the gains we have already made.
OUTLAYS
Total outlays are estimated to increase by 12.6 per cent in 1981-82, to $40,862 million. This represents an estimated increase in real terms of a little under 2 per cent.

The growth in outlays in 1981-82 is affected by an additional payday for public servants and most social security benefit recipients. Adjusted for this special factor, outlays would increase by about 11 1/2 per cent in nominal terms or less than 1 per cent in real terms.
Within total outlays, particular priority has been give to defence, pensions and other cash benefits and foreign aid.
In total, provisions for these purposes are estimated to rise by 15.8 per cent in 1981- 82; the increase for all other purposes is 10.4 per cent.

I turn now to some particular expenditure provisions; additional details are contained in the accompanying Budget documents, notably Statement No. 3. Relevant Ministers will be releasing further information as appropriate.
DEFENCE
The Government continues to give high priority to the strengthening of our national security.
The Defence provision of $4,112 million represents an increase of 16.3 per cent in current prices or 5.3 per cent in real terms.
This increase reflects the continuing implementation of the planned improvements in Australia's defence capability announced by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Defence in February 1980.

The proportion of defence outlays to be spent on capital equipment is a little lower than had been planned because of contractual and other delays which have affected spending in this area, notably on the tactical fighter program.
The Minister for Defence will advise the Parliament of further details later in the year.
SOCIAL WELFARE

Total expenditure on social security and welfare is estimated at $11,357m, an increase of 14.5 per cent. After allowing for the additional pension payday in 1981-82, the increase is about 12 per cent.
This Budget provides for some new initiatives in areas of particular need whilst also demonstrating our continuing commitment in the family area.
Family Allowances

Prior to the last election the Government stated that any significant increase in oil revenue in 1980-81 over the Budget estimate would be returned to Australian families. In the event, receipts from this source last year were actually below the Budget estimate, as I have already indicated.
Nevertheless, we have reviewed the levels of family allowances and decided to increase the rates of assistance for third and subsequent children by 50 per cent, with effect from 1 January 1982.

This means that the rates for the third and fourth child will be increased from $26 a month to $39 a month. For the fifth and each subsequent child, the rate will increase from $30.35 to $45.55 a month. A family with 5 children will therefore gain by $41.20 a month.
The rate for children in institutions will be increased from $21.70 a month to $39 a month.
In total, some 540 000 families will benefit.
These changes are estimated to cost $62m in 1981-82 and $124m in a full year.
Indexation of Pensions and Benefits

Basic pension and benefit rates will continue to be adjusted in line with movements in the Consumer Price Index. In November the standard or single rate of social service pension, for example, will rise by $3.05 to $69.70 a week, while the combined married rate will increase by $5.10 to $116.20 a week.
These new rates will represent increases of $5.60 and $9.40 respectively since November 1980.
Supplementary Rental Assistance

In recognition of the particular hardship suffered by many needy pensioners in rented accommodation, we have decided to increase and redirect the program of rental assistance to pensioners and long-term sickness beneficiaries so as to provide more support to those paying higher rents.

From the first pension payday in February 1982 the maximum rate of assistance will be increased by $3 to $8 a week. At the same time the rate of rent subsidy will be reduced from $1 for each $1 of rent paid, to 50 cents for each $1 of rent in excess of $10 a week.
The income test will be eased for single persons to provide a $1 for $2 rate of withdrawal in all cases.
New public housing tenants will not be eligible for such assistance.
Present rates and conditions for assistance will continue to apply for those current recipients who would otherwise be made worse off by these new arrangements.
The changes are estimated to cost an additional $20m in 1981-82 and about $50m in a full year.
Unemployment Benefits
The non-indexed rate of unemployment benefits for persons 18 years and over without dependants will be increased from $53.45 a week to $58.10 a week in November 1981.
Assistance for the Handicapped

This Government has provided substantial support for the mentally and physically handicapped since it came to office. The total provision of $1134m for handicapped people in 1981-82 represents an increase of $666m or 140 per cent over the comparable provision in 1975-76.
New measures provided in this the International Year of Disabled Persons are:
$1.5m as part of a $5m three year program to improve access and facilities in Commonwealth buildings for disabled persons;
$690 000 to establish work preparation centres in Perth, Adelaide and Brisbane for mildly retarded young people;
an increase from $5 to $8 a week in the incentive allowance payable to all sheltered employment allowees; and

almost $1.4m to assist in the production of braille and audio books, the improvement of radio and TV services for the handicapped, and the provision of sport and recreation facilities for the disabled.
Aged Persons' Accommodation and Crisis Accommodation

Other welfare measures in 1981-82 include a $12m increase in expenditure on aged persons' accommodation to $58m, and the provision of $2m to commence a crisis accommodation program for families in distress.
Assistance to Veterans
The Budget extends eligibility for repatriation benefits and service pensions and also provides for increases in a number of repatriation benefits.
The Minister for Veterans' Affairs will announce details but the main points are:
counselling centres for Vietnam veterans will be established in each State capital and Darwin;
Australian mariners who served in a theatre of war during the Second World War will become eligible for service pensions from February 1982;

for service pensioners, the amount of disability pension disregarded in the income test for pension and associated fringe benefits will be increased from 50 per cent to 60 per cent from January 1982; and
the maximum rate or repatriation funeral benefit will be increased from $300 to $400.
These measures are estimated to cost $6m in 1981-82 and $22m in a full year.
Assistance for Aboriginals
In recognition of their special needs, this Budget provides $147m for Aboriginals, a 16 per cent increase on last year.
This includes $8m as the first instalment of the Government's election commitment to provide $50m over five years for Aboriginal environmental health improvements.
The Aboriginal Development Commission, which emphasises self-help for Aboriginals, will receive $47.8m in 1981-82, including a $9m addition to the Commission's accumulating capital investment fund.
HEALTH
The Government has already announced important changes to the funding of health services in 1981-82.
Total outlays for health services in 1981-82 are estimated at $2872m.
Additional payments totalling $1151m will also be made to the States and the Northern Territory as the health component of the financial assistance provided in the revised tax sharing arrangements.
In all, these payments are $373m or 10.2 per cent higher than last year.
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme

The Government has decided to grant pharmaceutical manufacturers and wholesalers increases in PBS drug prices from 1 November 1981. The decision provides for an increase of 3.5 per cent on the price to chemists, plus 10 cents per benefit item.
These increases are estimated to cost $9m in 1981-82 and $18m in a full year.

The decision by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to increase chemists' remuneration for dispensing prescriptions is estimated to add a further $33.4 million, including retrospective payments of $10.9 million, to the cost of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme in 1981-82.

Given these cost increases the Government has decided to increase the current patient contribution by 45 cents to $3.20 for each benefit item prescribed, effective from 1 December 1981. Those presently exempt from paying contributions will remain exempt.
This increase will offset the costs of the Scheme by $10 million in 1981-82 and $20 million in a full year.
CULTURE AND RECREATION
A total of $461 million has been provided for cultural and recreational activities in 1981-82.

The National Broadcasting and Television Service will receive $273 million, an increase of $50 million. The Australian Broadcasting Commission will receive almost $234 million, including $12.1 million for the Commission as host broadcaster for the 1982 Commonwealth Games and $16 million to meet employer superannuation liabilities which fall on the ABC for the first time in 1981-82. An amount of $9.7 million is also provided to improve and extend the National Broadcasting and Television Service network, including facilities used for Radio Australia.
Other expenditures include:
$26 million to the Special Broadcasting Service for ethnic radio services and for the first full year of operations of multicultural television;
$29 million for the Australia Council, including a special allocation for the Commonwealth Games Arts Festival;
$25 million for the National Gallery, which is planned to open in October 1982; and
$6.6 million for the development of international standard sporting facilities in co-operation with the States and the Territories.
IMMIGRATION PROGRAMS
Although the Assisted Migration Program is being discontinued, provision is being made for an expected migrant intake of up to 120 000 in 1981-82, compared with 111 000 last year.

Funding for the programs established on the recommendations of the Galbally Committee is being maintained, pending the review during 1981-82 of programs reaching the end of the initial triennium. An amount of $31.3 million is provided to maintain the Adult Migrant Education Program at its present level.
FOREIGN AID

The Budget provides for an increase of over $100 million or 18 per cent in foreign aid expenditure. This is estimated to raise the ration of official development assistance to GDP from 0.43 per cent in 1980-81 to 0.45 per cent in 1981-82.
My colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs will be making a full statement on this program later in the Parliament.
EDUCATION
Details of funding for the Commonwealth Tertiary Education and Schools Commission programs have already been announced.
Total direct outlays on education are estimated to rise by 11.1 per cent in 1981-82 to $3,255 million.

This provision continues the priority given to technical and further education and to vocational programs. It also includes a further $35 million under the Commonwealth's five year school to work transition program.

Within the schools sector, increased priority will be given to particular areas of need, with migrant and special education receiving an additional $11 million and the country areas program an additional $1.2 million.
The progressive implementation of the Government's 1980 election commitment to raise the subsidy levels applicable to non-government schools is estimated to cost almost $28 million in 1981-82.
Student Assistance
The Government is taking steps to adjust certain student assistance programs.

The Secondary Allowances Scheme and the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme will be made more accessible to refugees, migrants and other students whose special circumstances make it difficult for them to gain fully from these schemes.

The allowance under the Secondary Allowances Scheme will be increased by 10 per cent from the beginning of 1982 and the income test requirements governing eligibility for tertiary and secondary allowances will be eased.
EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING PROGRAMS

Expenditure on programs designed to expand the supply of skilled labour sought by industry and to assist young people in their search for employment is to be increased by 22 per cent to $203 million in 1981-82.
This total includes $65 million-$24 million more than last year-to assist young unemployed people to obtain prior work experience and practical job skills or otherwise prepare them for employment.
Some 100 000 apprentices, 5000 more than last year, will be assisted through the CRAFT and special apprentice training schemes in 1981-82 at a total cost of $76 million.
Expenditure on school to work transition allowances will rise by $8 million to $13 million.
A total of $20 million-an increase of 35 per cent-is being allocated for training in skills which are in short supply, including in the metal and electrical trades and in the construction industry.

In the light of the increases in these programs, the Government has decided to terminate the Community Youth Support Scheme on 31 October 1981. This will allow available funds to be concentrated on programs more attuned to labour market conditions.
ASSISTANCE TO INDUSTRY
Rural Assistance

Existing programs of budgetary assistance to rural industries are being maintained, at an estimated net cost of $226 million in 1981-82. This includes $19.2 million for rural research and $17.7 million for the Rural Adjustment Scheme.
Export Incentives

The Budget includes $281 million for export expansion and export market development grants in 1981-82, an increase of $21 million which will permit a substantial reduction in the carry-over of outstanding claims.

The Government recently announced that grant rates under the Export Expansion Grants Scheme will be reduced by 50 per cent from 1 July 1982 and that both this Scheme and the Export Market Development Grants Scheme will be extended by one year to June 1983 pending their review by the Industries Assistance Commission.
Research and Development

As part of its response to the recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia, the Government initiated a further five year research and development program from 1 July this year.
The Budget provides $50m for industrial research and development grants, broadly the same amount as in 1980-81.
Energy Programs
Energy research is to be given further impetus with a provision of $14.9m in 1981-82. Coupled with this will be an allocation of $1.6m for energy conservation and energy information programs.

The Budget provides $2m to the Bureau of Mineral Resources for a geophysical study of the Bass Basin region. This work will complement private sector activity in the search for new hydrocarbon reserves.
Other Assistance
The Government will provide $129m in 1981-82 for the Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme, an increase of almost $9m over last year.
Support will be provided for a further three year joint Commonwealth/Industry program for the development of the Interscan microwave landing system.
The Budget also provides $49.8m for bounties for the textiles industry; these are being introduced as part of the revised assistance arrangements to apply to this industry from 1 January 1982.
NATIONAL WATER RESOURCES PROGRAM
A total of $35m has been allocated for the National Water Resources Program in 1981-82, an increase of 20 per cent on last year's allocation.
TRANSPORT
Air Transport

The Government has decided to increase air navigation charges for domestic trunk airlines by 12.5 per cent, regional airlines by 25 per cent and the general aviation sector by 20 per cent. These increases are effective from 1 October 1981; overall, the level of cost recovery from these sectors is expected to decline slightly.
To reduce the level of over-recovery of costs from international airlines, charges for that sector are to be lowered by 5 per cent with effect from 1 October 1981.
These variations are expected to yield net additional recoveries of $3.5m in 1981-82 and $5.3m in a full year.
Roads

The Budget provides $685m for roads grants to the States and the Northern Territory in 1981-82, $57m more than last year. These grants form part of the Commonwealth's undertaking to provide a total of $3650m for roads over the five years to 1984-85.
Shipping
An amount of $32.7m is provided for the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme; the Government is currently reviewing this Scheme to assess its performance in relation to its intended objectives.
Rail
The Budget includes $3m as part of a $10m program for the planning of the proposed Alice Springs to Darwin standard guage railway.
HOUSING
Total expenditure on housing programs is estimated to increase by 17 per cent, to $399m.
Welfare Housing
The Commonwealth has undertaken to provide the States and the Northern Territory with a base amount of $200m a year for welfare housing for each of the next five years.
This year we are allocating $262m for welfare housing, including the transfer of $12m from the States Grants for Aboriginal Housing program.

Of this total, $116m, including the whole of the $62m above the base amount, is in the form of non-repayable grants while $146m is allocated as repayable loans at the highly concessional interest rate of 4.5 per cent.
Homes Savings Grants

Following last year's initiative to increase substantially the maximum value limit for homes savings grants and to provide a family bonus, expenditure on this scheme is estimated to increase by over $29m to $74m in 1981-82.
PAYMENTS TO THE STATES, NORTHERN TERRITORY AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT
The major decisions affecting payments to the States have already been announced.
Total net payments to the States, the Northern Territory and local government, including all specific purpose payments, are estimated to increase by $1059m or 8 per cent in 1981-82.
STAFF CEILINGS
The Government is continuing to maintain firm restraint over its own administrative costs.
Provisional staff ceilings provide for a reduction of about 9000, or almost 3 per cent, in staff ceilings control during the course of 1981-82.
This is in line with the Government's decision to reduce, abolish or transfer certain Commonwealth functions and to aim for an additional 2 per cent cut in staff covered by ceilings over two years.
CIVIL WORKS
Public works expenditures also are being firmly restrained and the 1981-82 provision of $262m represents an increase of just over 5 per cent.

This provision will allow a limited number of high priority new projects to commence, including further upgrading of airport facilities for the operation of wide-bodied domestic jet aircraft, upgrading of Adelaide Airport for international services and rebuilding and upgrading of Australia's Antarctic bases.
COMMONWEALTH ENTERPRISES
Australian Postal and Telecommunications Commissions

The Government has decided to increase the interest rates payable on the capital advances by the Commonwealth which were taken over by the Postal and Telecommunications Commisssions on their inception in 1975. The average rates of interest on such advances will be increased from about 5.2 per cent and 6.9 per cent, respectively, to 10 per cent with effect from 1 January 1982. The resultant increase in revenue is estimated to be about $60m in 1981-82, and $120m in a full year.

In addition, the terms of the outstanding advances will be consolidated with a view to being progressively converted, over a ten-year cycle commencing in 1982-83, at the semi-government rate of interest prevailing on 1 January preceding the year of conversion.
These measures will put the operations of Australia Post and Telecom on a more commercial footing.
Australian Shipping Commission

The Australian Shipping Commission has advised that it will make early repayment of interest bearing Budget advances totalling $30m in 1981-82 as a result of refinancing arrangements to be made on commercial considerations.
RECEIPTS
I turn now to the revenue proposals and estimates, details of which are presented in Statement No. 4.

In line with our election undertaking, a half indexation adjustment was made to the personal income tax scale and dependant rebates with effect from 1 July 1981. That measure is estimated to cost $495m in 1981-82 and $525m in a full year.

In addition, legislation has already been passed to introduce a tax rebate for basic health insurance contributions. This measure, which will be reflected in tax refund cheques next year, is estimated to cost $600m in a full year.
This Budget also allows for a number of other recently announced taxation measures.

Some of the new revenue proposals which the Treasurer will announce tonight will help to broaden the tax base and this, combined with measures in other areas, will enhance the potential for further personal income tax relief in future years.

In addition to measures to contain expenditures and broaden the tax base, the Government is continuing its efforts to stamp out tax avoidance. I mention in particular the replacement of the old section 260 by the broader general anti-avoidance provisions, which have attracted wide suppport within the community.
The Treasurer has also announced the Government's intention to tighten section 136, which is directed at tax avoidance in international business transactions.
Sales Tax

For reasons that were announced at the time, the Government decided earlier this year against a major restructuring of the tax system towards greater reliance on broadly based indirect taxes. That decision did not rule out later consideration of smaller adjustments within the present system.

It is clear that there is advantage in some change in the mix of direct and indirect taxes to increase the potential for desirable reductions in direct taxes, and particularly personal income tax, as economic and budgetary conditions permit.

To this end the Government has decided to increase by 2 1/2 per cent each of the existing rates of sales tax, effective in relation to goods passing the taxing point after tonight. The necessary legislation will be introduced in the House of Representatives this evening.
This increase in rates is estimated to yield $314m in 1981-82 and $420m in a full year.

The legislation will also provide for the correction of a significant number of anomalies and inconsistencies in the sales tax law; the estimated net revenue gains are $107m in 1981-82 and $142m in a full year.

In addition, the Government will be bringing in legislation as soon as practicable to tax, at a rate of 2 per cent, a range of goods that are now exempt-such as clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings, manchester; building materials; books, magazines and newspapers; packaging and wrapping materials; hand tools; and certain other goods but not including medicines, food or wine. To the extent that the goods in question are covered by other over-riding exemptions applicable to particular industries or organisations (including governments), they will retain their exempt status.
This measure, which will have effect with respect to goods passing the taxing point on or after 1 January 1982, is estimated to raise $132m of additional revenue in 1981-82 and $330m in a full year.
Further details will be given in the amending legislation.
Excises
I turn now to the question of excises.
There have been no increases in the excise on refined petroleum products, beer or spirits or tobacco products for several years.
There will be no increases in these excises in this Budget.
Coal Export Duty

At present, the coal export duty applies to exports of coking coal, at rates of either $3.50 per tonne or $1 per tonne depending on the quality of the coal and certain other features of the mining operation. There is no duty on steaming coal.
The present rates are below those which applied when the Government came into office but it is no longer considered appropriate to phase out the duty, which was the intention some years ago.

Rather, developments in the world market for energy resources and the consequential strengthening of export demand for steaming coal indicate that there is no longer any reason to differentiate between coking coal and steaming coal in the application of the duty.
The $1 per tonne rate will therefore be extended to exports after 8 p.m. tonight of black coal not at present subject to duty.
Deductions for Capital Expenditure of Mining Businesses

Very generous income tax deductions are allowed for capital expenditure incurred in the development of a mining property or an oil or natural gas field. In 1976, when the mining industry was in the doldrums, deductions calculated by reference to a maximum statutory life of a mine or field of 5 years were introduced; this was increased to 6 years in the Review of Commonwealth Functions announced in April 1981.

With the resources investment boom now proceeding apace, there is no longer justification for the continuation of this specially favourable tax regime for this sector of the economy. Accordingly, it has been decided to increase the maximum statutory life to 10 years.

There will be no gain to revenue from this measure in 1981-82. The first full-year yield is estimated at $85m. The yield will be less than that in 1982-83, but is expected to build up gradually to $250m or more by about the mid-1980s.
Depreciation Allowances on Plant used to
produce Basic Iron and Steel

In the light of the far reaching importance of the iron and steel industry in the Australian economy, the Government has decided to allow accelerated write-off for income tax purposes of capital expenditure on plant and equipment used exclusively to produce basic iron and steel.

Eligible plant ordered under a contract entered into after today will be depreciable at a special rate of 20 per cent per annum where the current schedule life for taxation purposes is 5 years or more, and at 33 1/3 per cent where it is less than 5 years.
These new provisions will apply until 1991. Full details will be provided with the legislation.
Industry Assistance-IAC Reference

The Government has decided to ask the Industries Assistance Commission to report on certain budgetary forms of assistance currently provided to industry and on possible changes or redirections which would be more cost-effective.
At present, industry benefits from a wide range of measures-from direct grants and subsidies to taxation measures-which have significant budgetary implications.

Consistent with its overall policy of fiscal restraint, and its desire to encourage the development of more efficient and internationally competitive industries, the Government wishes to ensure the maximum cost-effectiveness of these measures.
Details of the reference will be announced shortly.
Stamp Duties in the Australian Capital
Territory

At present, stamp duties in the Australian Capital Territory apply to a narrower range of instruments and transactions than those in the States. Moreover, most of the rates applying in the Territory have not been altered since they were introduced in 1than those in the States. Accordingly, we have decided to bring the range and levels of Australian Capital Territory stamp duties more into line with those of the States.
The changes are estimated to yield $5 million in 1981-82 and $6 million in a full year.
Departure Tax and Passport Fees

The Government has decided to increase the rate of departure tax from $10 to $20 and to lower the taxable age from 18 years to 12 years. These changes will take effect from 1 October 1981 and are estimated to yield $15 million in 1981-82 and $20 million in a full year.
Fees for passports are to rise by $5 to $30 with effect from tomorrow.
Commercial Radio and Television Station Licence Fees

A new structure for fees payable by commercial radio and television station licensees is to be introduced. This will raise revenue from this source to an estimated $31.5 million in 1981-82. The Minister for Communications will announce the details.
Zone Allowance
The Public Inquiry into Income Tax Zone Allowances, announced in the 1980-81 Budget Speech, has now reported and the Treasurer will be tabling the report tonight.

In the main report, the Inquiry suggested that additional assistance be directed to taxpayers with families and to those living in especially isolated areas, and that certain other changes be made to the system.
The recommendations of the main report have largely been accepted by the Government; the changes are to take effect from 1 November 1981.
The full-year revenue cost is estimated at $10 million.
Friendly Society Dispensaries
The Government has decided to change the basis on which dispensaries conducted by friendly societies are subject to tax.

Beginning with income derived in the 1982-83 income year, dispensaries will be taxed like other non-profit companies, at normal company rates on a net profits basis, inclusive of investment income but exclusive of profits arising from transactions with members. The revenue consequences of the change will be small.
The Small Investor

The Government attaches great importance to the part played in our economy by small investors; in this connection, we have been examining the present income tax treatment of persons with modest shareholdings.

The Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System is, however, expected to report soon in some depth on this matter, and we have therefore decided to defer any decisions until we have studied relevant sections of the Committee's Report.
BUDGET OVERVIEW
Total outlays in 1981-82 are estimated to increase by 12.6 per cent to $40,862 million.
Total receipts, after allowance for the measures I have just outlined, are estimated to increase by 15.8 per cent to $40,716 million.

The overall Budget deficit is therefore estimated at $146 million, a reduction of $981 million on the outcome for 1980-81. On present estimates the deficit expressed as a proportion of GDP will be a mere 0.1 per cent in 1981-82, compared with a peak of 4.9 per cent in 1975-76.
After allowance for transactions abroad, there will be an estimated Budget domestic surplus of $1,542 million.
ECONOMIC OUTLOOK
As the figures I have just quoted show, this Budget represents a decisive response, in the area of fiscal policy, to mounting wage and cost pressures.

By restraining the growth in total outlays the Budget will curb public sector demands on real resources at a time when those resources are being keenly sought by expanding businesses in the private sector.

It will also significantly reduce the total public sector requirement for loanable funds in 1981-82 at a time when the corporate sector is likely to be seeking substantially larger borrowings to help finance its investment program.
This will help to ease the pressures which, otherwise, that increase in private borrowings would produce.

For a variety of reasons monetary conditions last year were more accommodating than had been intended; one illustration of this is that M3 increased by 12.7 per cent during the course of 1980-81 compared with the Budget projection of about 9 to 11 per cent.

While there are many unpredictable influences on the money supply-including external developments in particular-it is fundamental to winding back inflation that growth in the monetary aggregates also be wound back.
In particular, we are determined not to allow the money supply to expand so as to accommodate a new round of excessive wage increases.
In these circumstances, it is clearly desirable that the rate of growth of the money supply be reduced.

The Government will therefore be seeking to restrain growth in the monetary aggregates to a degree consistent with growth in M3 of 10 to 11 per cent over the course of 1981-82. The sharply reduced Commonwealth Budget deficit will facilitate this task but an appropriate balance of other domestic and external policies will also be required.

The increases in tap stock yield announced after last week's Loan Council meeting, taken together with this Budget, will make a major contribution towards reducing pressures on interest rates, settling capital markets and restraining monetary growth.
As in recent years, arrangements will be made for the forthcoming wheat harvest to be financed in a manner consistent with monetary objectives.

This tightening of fiscal and monetary policies is designed to prevent an acceleration in the underlying rate of inflation in 1981-82. Avoiding that acceleration is essential to restoring the conditions for a downward movement in 1982-83 and later years.

It is to be hoped that current developments in the wages area will lead to more flexible and more orderly wage determination processes which pay proper regard to the economy's capacity to bear wage increases. I have already referred to the responsibilities on all parties in this regard.

Given developments to date, however, it appears that average weekly earnings in 1981-82 could rise by about 13 1/2 per cent. This would be much the same as in 1980-81, when the rise in earnings was enlarged by the flow through of the so-called 'work value' round of wage increases which began in 1978.
On that basis, the forecast rise in the Consumer Price Index in 1981-82 as a whole is about 10 3/4 per cent.

Leaving aside the effects of the revenue measures mentioned in the Budget and the previously announced changes in health care arrangements, the rise would be a little under 9 1/2 per cent-an underlying rate of inflation much the same as that recorded in 1980-81.

The tighter policy framework which is now essential for containing inflationary pressures does of course carry some implications in the short-term for activity and employment. Nevertheless, the non-farm sector of the economy should continue to grow strongly in 1981-82.

Business fixed investment, in particular, seems certain to grow rapidly again this year. The rate of that expansion-especially in the building and construction sector-will depend importantly on the availability of materials and skilled labour, including the extent to which supplies of both can be augmented from overseas.
Given continued strong growth in real household incomes, personal consumption expenditure could rise a little faster in 1981-82-perhaps by around 3 1/2 per cent.

Private dwelling investment, however, is likely to decline somewhat in 1981-82 after rapid increases in each of the past two years. This will in part reflect a reduction in investment and speculative activity.

The Government continues to attach a high priority to maintaining a steady flow of private housing finance. The availability of such finance will be affected, of course, by the relative competitiveness of interest rates offered and hence the rates charged by housing finance institutions. As this Budget demonstrates, the Government has made major efforts to reduce public sector pressures on capital markets in the interests of limiting the competitive pressures on housing finance and interest rates.

On present indications gross non-farm product could grow by between 3 and 3 1/2 per cent this year-below the 4 per cent rate estimated for 1980-81, but higher than the average rate of about 2 1/2 per cent in the second half of the 1970s.
With farm production expected to recover in 1981-82, gross domestic product could rise by more than 3 1/2 per cent this year, compared with about 3 per cent last year.

This outlook is considered to be consistent with employment growth of about 2 per cent in 1981-82. This would be below the increases of about 2 1/2 per cent recorded in each of the past two years but would still represent strong growth in employment, particularly by standards in other industrialised economies today.

A further strong increase in imports is likely in 1981-82 but any recovery in the level of exports will be limited by the continued sluggishness in word trade-a fact which underlines the paramount need for Australia not to throw away the international competitiveness so hard won over recent years.
Taken together with the prospect for invisibles, this means that the current account deficit may widen further in 1981-82 to around 4 1/2 per cent of GDP.

Though the outlook for the balance of payments is as always subject to many uncertainties, it seems reasonable to expect this current account deficit to be covered by private capital inflow-provided that, as we are determined they shall be, wage demands and inflation are successfully contained. In those circumstances a surplus on private sector foreign exchange transactions of a similar order of magnitude to the $2,800m recorded last year could occur.
CONCLUSION
It is vital to the nation's interests that there be no acceleration in the rate of inflation in 1981-82.
Such an outcome would have most adverse consequences for confidence-both here and abroad-in Australia's future and for the competitiveness of our industries.
This is especially so given that most of the major industrialised countries, led by the United States, are now bent on firm anti-inflation policies.
Australia has been doing better than many of these countries in containing inflationary pressures in recent years. Our aim is to keep it that way.
This Budget is an essential part of the Government's strategy for containing wage and price inflation. It will also help in a major way to ease pressures on interest rates.
The Budget is being supported-and will continue to be supported-by equally decisive action in monetary and other policy areas.

Such action is necessary if we are not only to preserve the hard won gains of the past but also if we are to exploit the potential for even greater gains in the years ahead from the large investments now under way, particularly in resource projects.
The Budget will also help to maintain further solid growth in private sector activity and to provide more jobs for Australians.
I commend the Budget to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his Budget Speech mentioned several changes in the social security area that will result from the 1981-82 Budget. I should now like to elaborate a little on what he has said and provide the Senate with some additional information. The Government has allocated $9865m in the Budget to pensions, benefits and other welfare payments and services provided through the Department of Social Security. This is $1265m more than was spent in 1980-81, representing an increase of 14.7 per cent. The main reason for this rise, apart from increases in the numbers of pensioners and beneficiaries, is the automatic indexation of the major pensions and benefits, introduced by the Government in 1976, to maintain the base rates of these payments. The annual cost of pension indexation is estimated to be $716m for increases that will be payable from November 1981 and May 1982 and the Budget allocation includes a sum of $281m to provide for these rises during the remainder of the 1981-82 financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: These figures illustrate not only the cost but also the degree of the Government's commitment to its policy of protecting basic pensions against inflation. The Government regards automatic rises in the basic rate of pensions and benefits in line with consumer price index increases as a crucial element in ensuring social justice for people whose major or only source of income support is their pension. Since coming into office in 1975 the Government's application of its indexation policy has meant that the standard rate of pension has risen by $27.90, or over 70 per cent, in line with consumer price index movements. Sickness benefits for people 18 years and over and unemployment benefits for those with dependants have been adjusted in the same way. In the same period the upper limits at which people can receive some pension payment have risen by $55.80 to $153.30 a week for a single person and by $93.20 to $256.70 a week for a married couple.

Under the pension indexation policy, the basic rate of social security pensions and benefits will rise by $3.05 a week for a single person and by $5.10 a week for a married couple from November. Some 1.9 million pensioners and beneficiaries will receive the increased payments. The new rates will be in line with the increase of 4.6 per cent in the consumer price index between the December quarter 1980 and the June quarter 1981. The standard rate of single pension or benefit will be $69.70 a week and the rate for a married couple will be $116.20 a week. In the case of age, invalid, wives' and widows' pensions and supporting parents benefits the new rates will operate from the first pay-day in November, that is, Thursday, 5 November. In the case of unemployment, sickness and special benefits the first payment of the new rates will be made on the individual beneficiaries first payday after 1 November 1981.

The Government has also decided to increase the rate of unemployment benefit paid to people aged 18 years and over who have no dependants. This rate will rise by $4.65 to $58.10 a week from the first benefits pay-day in November. In addition to the increased amounts necessary to cover rises in the numbers of pensioners and beneficiaries and the indexation commitment, the Budget allocations for the Department of Social Security include $244m for an extra pension pay-day this year. There will be 27 instead of the usual 26 pension pay-days in 1981-82.

The other main elements in the Budget allocations to the Department of Social Security are to cover new government initiatives to assist large families by increasing family allowance rates for third and subsequent children, to increase and redirect supplementary assistance provisions towards those pensioners who are paying higher rents, and to increase the allocations to assist handicapped and aged people and for children's services. In the context of its commitment to the welfare of Australian families, the Government has decided to increase substantially assistance to families, with three or more children. In doing this, it is recognising the special needs of large families.

The Government is committed to enhancing the position of all families. Australian families bringing up children are perhaps the greatest beneficiaries of sound, responsible economic management. Such management requires continued restraint on outlays so that taxes and inflation can be kept as low as possible. Within this context, the Government decided this year to pay particular attention to larger families. Such families have been identified by many groups, including the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty, as being particularly vulnerable to economic hardship. Wage determination no longer involves consideration of the needs of families and wages are therefore less likely to cover the needs of large families than small families. From January 1982, the rates of family allowance for third and subsequent children will be increased by 50 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The payment in respect of the 10,000 children being cared for in institutions will be increased from $21.70 to $39.00 a month. In total, some 540,000 families will benefit by these new arrangements. The cost of this initiative in the current financial year will be $62m, representing $124m in a full year.
