SPEECH.PARA: Last year the Government substantially increased assistance for children of pensioners and beneficiaries. Additional pension/benefit was increased by 33 per cent and mother's/guardian's allowance was also increased. In addition, the handicapped child's allowance and double orphan's pension were increased. Over the past five years the Government has also been very mindful of the difficulties facing single income families. As a result, the Government has regularly increased both the dependent spouse and sole parent tax rebates. These have been increased again in 1981-82, the dependent spouse rebate from $800 to $830 and the sole parent rebate from $559 to $580.

The Government has given particular attention in this Budget to helping other groups in special need and in this context has decided to change, from February 1982, the system of supplementary assistance or allowance payable to pensioners, including supporting parent beneficiaries, and sickness beneficiaries, who pay rent. The changes to be made will direct most assistance to those paying higher rents in the private rental market, will provide a higher maximum rate of assistance and will introduce a more gradual income test.

The maximum rate of rental assistance will rise by $3 to $8 a week and, to ensure that assistance is concentrated on those pensioners and beneficiaries who have to pay higher rents, it will be paid only for rents in excess of $10 a week at the rate of 50 cents for each $1 of rent above this amount up to a maximum rate of $8 at rents of $26 or more. The income test for rental assistance will be changed so that the amount received will be reduced by a withdrawal rate of 50 per cent of the pensioner's assessable income. Tenants of State or Territory housing authorities will not be eligible for assistance under the new provisions because they are already, in effect, receiving an element of government subsidy.

These new provisions, which will ensure that in future more assistance will be available to those pensioners and beneficiaries paying higher amounts of rent, will not operate to the disadvantage of any existing pensioners and beneficiaries. In cases where people would be made worse off by the changes they will continue to receive assistance on the basis of current rates and conditions. The related income-test-free incentive allowance for all people who receive a sheltered employment allowance will also be increased to $8 a week.

Other means by which the concentration of assistance to those most in need will be pursued include: Strengthening the provisions in the Social Services Act against schemes contrived, through artificial reductions in income, to qualify people for pensions and pensioner concessions they do not really need; the development of a crisis accommodation program with special emphasis on the needs of families; and new arrangements about the circumstances in which people caring for refugee children may be eligible to receive an orphans pension.

The Government is concerned that, in the welfare area as well as in taxation, income rigging practices are circumventing the intent of the laws and throwing undue burdens on taxpayers generally. In turn such practices make it more difficult to help genuinely needy people. The Social Services Act already has provisions aimed at preventing people who are well able to maintain themselves from deliberately arranging their affairs so that they become eligible for higher rates of pension. These provisions, like the pension income test, are an essential part of the mechanisms for ensuring that available assistance is focused on those who are least protected and that the already large demands made by the welfare system on taxpayers are not further increased.

It has become evident that there is a growing practice of avoiding income for pension purposes, or even more commonly for pensioner fringe benefits. There is no essential difference, so far as the general community effect is concerned, between this and tax avoidance. It is, quite simply, the welfare face of the income rigging coin. We shall therefore be moving during the Budget session of Parliament to tighten up the relevant legislation so as to prevent income avoidance for pension purposes by such devices as keeping large sums of capital in non-interest bearing accounts or by participation in other income avoidance schemes that are being promoted within the community. For example, there are schemes which produce no 'income' to pensioners but enable them to withdraw capital equal to the amount of income that would be payable under a normal investment arrangement. In other words, income is withdrawn in the guise of capital. The new provisions will not operate to penalise people if they liquidate income-producing assets for reasonable purposes, such as the purchase of a home, a car, or a holiday. Similarly, they will not operate to prevent people from keeping reasonable amounts of money in non-interest bearing current accounts.

In the area of crisis accommodation, my colleague, the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) and I will be taking up with the States the development of a special program of crisis accommodation for families for which $2m has been allocated by the Commonwealth in 1981-82. This will be in addition to the $6.3m allocated for the Homeless Persons Assistance Program which my Department administers.

The Social Services Act will be amended during the year to bring certain refugee children within the definition of a 'double orphan'. At present, a person who has the care of a child both of whose parents are dead, or when one parent is dead and the whereabouts of the other is unknown, is entitled to a double orphan's pension of $55.70 a month. In the case of a refugee child, it is often a question of not knowing whether the parents are alive or dead or not knowing where they are. In some cases the parents are known to be overseas, but the parent and the child cannot be reunited and the parent cannot provide economic support. The circumstances of these children are similar to those of 'double orphans' so the Government proposes to pay a double orphan's pension to people who are caring for refugee children whose parents are not in Australia or whose whereabouts are unknown.

To correct anomalies in the provisions governing eligibility for some pensions and benefits the Government has decided to amend the Social Services Act in relation to the granting of a wife's pension and the payment of unemployment benefit to the spouses of certain people. Recent legal advice to the Government has disclosed a weakness in the operation of the Social Services Act in relation to the administration of wives' pensions. This means that these pensions may currently be granted to women resident overseas even if they have never lived in Australia, while other pensions require the applicant to be resident in Australia. The proposed amendment will ensure uniformity of treatment for applicants for all types of pensions by bringing wives' pensions into line with the broad policy that if an Australian pension is to be payable abroad it must be in force when the pensioner leaves Australia.

It is also proposed to amend the Act to prevent payment of unemployment benefit to the spouse of a person engaged in industrial action or the spouse of a person who in certain circumstances has been refused unemployment benefit, or has had the benefit cancelled or postponed. An example would be where a person's unemployment benefit is cancelled because an offer of a job has been refused without good reason. People whose benefit is refused, cancelled or postponed in these circumstances will also be ineligible for special benefit, although their spouses may qualify for such a payment in cases where extreme hardship would otherwise result.

With the aim of providing a better service to clients in remote areas, my Department is to experiment with the use of paid agents as a point of contact for the receipt of pensions and benefits and for obtaining information about social security matters. In 1981-82 a pilot program, involving the appointment of 10 paid agents, will be conducted at a cost of $27,000. While the Department has undertaken in recent years an extensive decentralisation program involving the opening of many more local Social Security offices, there are still many remote areas where it is not practical for an office to be established. It is expected that the paid agents experiment will be of particular benefit to people in such areas, including remote Aboriginal communities.

In this, the International Year of Disabled Persons, the Government has further consolidated and developed its support for programs to assist mentally and physically disabled people. Both the Handicapped Persons Assistance Scheme and the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service administered by my Department have received increased allocations for the current financial year of $57.33m and $28.65m respectively.

We have decided to expand further the successful work preparation program for training mildly intellectually retarded young people. The success of this program is illustrated by the fact that during 1979-80 the Granville Centre in Sydney placed some 75 per cent of its clients in gainful employment, and follow-up studies show that this high rate of employment is maintained. The Government has decided, in addition to the two new centres currently being established in Sydney and Melbourne, to establish a further three new work preparation centres, one each in Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth. A further $300,000 will be provided to upgrade the quality and effectiveness of existing services for the handicapped.

In 1981-82 $300,000 will be provided for a new permanent scheme of assistance for the production and publication of braille and audio books for the print-handicapped. This is the first time that assistance in this area has been extended beyond braille. Taxation deductions will be provided for gifts made in 1981-82 to the Commonwealth and State committees for the International Year of Disabled Persons.

We have also, as I have mentioned, raised the incentive allowance for those in sheltered employment. These measures are only a limited part of the Commonwealth's recognition of the needs of the disabled, which are regarded as having special significance in this international year. In other subsidy programs through which the Government directs assistance to groups with particular needs, allocations have been increased to $58m for aged and disabled persons accommodation and $80.1m for children's services, including pre-schools.

In conclusion I would like to re-emphasise that the Government's attitude to the social security area in this Budget has been to maintain a steady course, introducing where possible worthwhile increases in provisions for those whose circumstances are such as to justify a special focus of assistance. Our approach reflects our concern to assist those in greatest need, against a background of overall expenditure restraint, and is the approach most likely to contribute to the overall welfare of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: - by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I do so, as I have for the past few years, to correct some of the imbalances in the statement of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), imbalances which result from its carefully selective nature. That is a practice which I suppose is understandable but one that is therefore also in need of balancing. It is worth while pointing out that initially the Minister correctly told the Senate that the main reason, almost the entire reason, for the increase in social security expenditure in the coming year is the automatic indexation of pensions and benefits-in cases in which they are in fact indexed. That action merely keeps them roughly in line with the level of inflation and with changes in the consumer price index, but extends no real benefit to such pensioners or beneficiaries. The second main reason is the increase that will occur next year in the number of pensioners and beneficiaries.

I take up the point made by the Minister that the Government has introduced worth while increases in the provision for those whose circumstances are such as to justify a special focus of assistance. It is beholden upon me, as spokesman for the Opposition, to point out those areas which the Government did not consider worthy of a special focus of assistance and to discuss just what has happened in those areas. The first and most obvious is the area of family allowances, which are to be raised for families with three or more children-in other words, for the third, fourth and fifth child and so on. The 50 per cent increase in the benefit in respect of even those children will not make up for the increase in the level of inflation which has been experienced since 1976, when these allowances were introduced. Even these families, which certainly need assistance, will not receive a family allowance at the same real level as those which were introduced with such fanfare in this Parliament in 1976.

Those who will benefit constitute only 26.4 per cent of all families with children. It is important to point out that they are not necessarily the poorest families in the community. Some one and a half million families or 73.6 per cent of all families with children, will receive no benefit at all from the proposed increase, and families on low incomes will be forced further below the poverty line. Pensioners, and families with an unemployed breadwinner and children, are all at the moment below the poverty line. Only 21 per cent of this group-those with more than two children-will obtain any benefit from this Budget. Some 163,000 or 79 per cent, of unemployed pensioner families will receive nothing.

If family allowances had been indexed since their introduction, a family with one child would now be receiving an extra $9.30 per month, a family with two children an extra $22.37 a month, a family with three children an extra $25.07 a month, a family with four children an extra $27.77 a month, and a family with five children an extra $32.82 a month. If family allowances had not been allowed to erode in value the Government would be spending another $280m this year instead of the $124m additional that is proposed. When family allowances were introduced we were told that they represented the greatest reform in social security that had been seen in this country. However, until the present moment they have not since been increased. Their value has eroded and that situation will continue.

Families on pensions and unemployment benefits and who are at the moment below the poverty line will remain below it and in most cases will go further and further below it. The proposed benefits will not go to the majority of families. They will go to large families, who badly need them of course, but not to small families-and the vast majority of poor families in this country have in fact one or two children. As a result of a scatter gun approach they will go across the board to the third, fourth and fifth children. Although we do not deny the need of those families there is a great group in this country which is in very difficult circumstances and is worthy of a special focus of assistance on the part of the Minister and of those government supporters who claim continually that they are concerned about the welfare of families in this country.

It is worth while pointing out that the adjustment that is to be made to unemployment benefits for those who have no dependents is far less than is reasonable, when one considers that other pensions and benefits have been indexed. It is even more worth while pointing out that the unemployment benefit for those who under 18 years of age remains at $36, which is the same as it was in 1975. Those who have to leave high unemployment rural areas to seek work in the city will find their benefit eroded further and further. This will add more and more to the problem of homeless and poor youth in this community that has faced us in recent years.

A particularly sad observation is the Minister's statement that the legislation is to be changed to prevent the spouses of those who are taking industrial action, or who for various reasons have been refused unemployment benefits, from receiving unemployment benefits even though at present they are eligible since they were in the work force and have qualified in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you notice that that part was omitted from the Budget Speech?

—It was omitted from the Budget Speech but was included in Senator Chaney's statement. The Minister said in his statement that, in fact, these people will get special benefit in cases of dire need. Special benefit is available at the moment only to people in dire need. Heaven knows what the Minister means when he adds that in this statement. We do not know what is meant by the Minister in this statement by extreme hardship when, in fact, under the present circumstances special benefits are available only to people who, by anybody's description, could only be considered to be in extreme hardship.

SPEECH.PARA: The social services legislation of this country is designed and meant to assist those in need. This is using the social services legislation for industrial relations purposes. It is a misuse of the legislation. It is a further demonstration of the absolute absence of a sensible industrial relations policy by the present Government. To use this legislation in this way, to penalise the wives and children of people involved in industrial action or people who have been refused benefit under the extremely loose provisions of the Act because they have been unable to get a job is an absolute disgrace. It is no wonder that the Treasurer, Mr Howard, omitted to mention this at all in his Budget Speech but left it to the Minister for Social Security to sneak it in on page 11 of a statement made in this place. It is a disgrace and it is a further demonstration of the need for the Government to go away, really learn what is happening in the community, do something about industrial relations and stop misusing the social services legislation which is, in fact, designed to help people.

In the area of aged persons housing we have a problem which has been recurring ever since this Government came to power. The Government promised that $225m was to be spent in a three-year housing program for the aged. This program, in fact, is $110m less in real terms than its predecessor which began as a three-year program and tapered off to be a five-year program with no additional money being spent. Last year $45.8m was spent, nearly $7m less than the allocation. This year $58m is allocated and even if it is spent it leaves another $120m to be spent in the last year of the program. As the Government has never spent more than $60m in a year in the time that it has been in power I suggest that this is an impossible target. It is a false target, as has been demonstrated in recent years. It is misleading those people and those members of organisations who are striving to assist with a very severe problem, a problem of accommodation for aged and disabled people in this community.

The Budget comes down every year and the Opposition and others of course get very little chance to study the whole areas that are of concern to us. I have touched on only a couple of the areas mentioned in the statement of the Minister for Social Security but even those areas demonstrate that the Government's avowed aim of assisting families is nonsense when one looks at the facts and figures in the Budget. The Government's promise made during the last election campaign that it would protect not only families but particularly low income families and those in greatest need is absolute nonsense when one looks at the increases in family allowances, at the way in which the young unemployed are treated and at the way in which the unemployed with dependents are treated in this Budget.

The Budget is dishonest in the one example to which I have drawn attention tonight when it claims that the Government is to maintain a high level of spending for aged accommodation, a claim it has made ever since it came into power. Outside the social security area, the increases in the cost of pharmaceuticals and the increases in the cost of health care for those people who fall just outside the disadvantaged status will mean that a vast number of people will be further disadvantaged, apart from those who do not receive their fair share of this country's wealth in this Budget. The statement again demonstrates how false and how callous are those people who wander around mouthing that they are concerned for the poor, the disadvantaged, the families, the children and the unemployed in this country. I dare say that as we study the documents further similar dishonest and misleading statements will be found. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I congratulate you on your appointment to the high office of President of the Senate and wish you a long and happy term. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) tonight announced certain measures affecting Australian veterans and their families. I would like to elaborate on his remarks for the benefit of honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, when reviewing the whole range of repatriation matters, had very much in mind the many representations made to it by the various ex-service organisations. Most of these requests were, no doubt, very worthy and if the Government had more money at its disposal it would have been able to increase a greater number of benefits or extend benefits to more categories of beneficiaries than it has. As it happens, we feel that we have been able to use such money as is available to give the greatest assistance to those most in need-that is, the more severely disabled veterans. This has been our main objective in each Budget over the last three years. Another objective has been gradually to extend eligibility for repatriation benefits, and so this year, with the funds at our disposal, the Government has been able to extend benefits to three new categories.

The first of these is the provision of the service pension to Australian mariners who served in a theatre of war during the 1939-45 war. The service pension, which is similar to the Department of Social Security's age pension, is available to veterans who served in a theatre of war and have reached the age of 60 years in the case of males or 55 in the case of females, or have become permanently unemployable at any age. Subject to an income test, certain fringe benefits are attached to the service pension, including pensioner health benefits and I am sure this new measure, which will apply from 4 February next year, will be very welcome. Repatriation benefits are also to be extended to members of peacekeeping, observation and monitoring forces representing Australia under United Nations--

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Sinai.

—Not like Sinai-under United Nations or other recognised international arrangements. This will apply to persons who serve in such forces after 1 November this year. In addition, disability pensions are to be paid to former members of the Royal Papuan Constabulary and the New Guinea Police Force who served under the control of the Australian New Guinea Army Unit from 7 December 1941 to 31 December 1945, although these police were not members of the forces they were subject to Army discipline and control. Benefits will be paid from the date of assent to the amending legislation under the same conditions as apply to indigenous members of the Australian forces during the Pacific War.

SPEECH.PARA: Service pensioners are to be assisted in another respect. The maximum amount of supplementary assistance-also known as the rent allowance-payable to a service pensioner is to be increased from $5 to $8 a week from 4 February next year. Supplementary assistance is given if a pensioner pays rent or pays for lodging, or board and lodging, but, from 4 February next year, if rent exceeds $10 a week, it will be paid only at the rate of 50c for each $1 of rent over that amount. In an important move affecting many veterans and their dependants, the proportion of any repatriation disability pension disregarded when assessing eligibility for the service pension and fringe benefits is to be increased from the present 50 per cent to 60 per cent from 1 January 1982. The income test has disregarded 50 per cent of any disability pension for service pension eligibility for some years, but for fringe benefits this has applied only from 1 January this year. The main effect of the increased proportion will be to make more people eligible for the service pension and to enable those who became eligible for it and the fringe benefits this year to retain them. I am sure that this will be a very popular move.

I said, Mr President, that the main thrust of the Government's concern for our veterans and their dependants has been to use what funds are available largely to improve benefits to the more severely disabled of our veterans. In this respect, I am pleased that we have been able to increase many of those allowances which were increased last year-for instance, additions to pensions for those suffering amputations or loss of vision are to be increased from 12 November by amounts ranging from 50 cents to $2.25, bringing the maximum addition for this purpose up to $28.05 weekly. From the same date there will be increases in the orphan's pension by $2.40 for orphans without parents, making a new pension of $30 a week, and by $1.20 to $15 a week for those with one parent. The attendant's allowance for the severely disabled will rise by $3.40 to $42.05 a week at the high rate and by $1.70 to $21.02 a week for the low rate. The recreation transport allowance will rise by $4.00 to 48.000 monthly at the high rate and by $2.00 to 24.00 monthly for the low rate. The gift car allowance will rise by $48 to $576 annually. The clothing allowance will also rise by 15c to bring the high rate to $1.80 a week, with proportional increases in the lower rates.

Allowances under the Soldiers' Children Education Scheme are to be increased from 7 January next year. There are six rates depending upon age and whether the student is living at home or away from home. The increases range from 45c to $2.20 and the weekly rates will now range from $5.45 to $27.20.

Two years ago, the Government was able to increase the maximum rate of funeral benefit in respect of the deaths of entitled veterans and some dependants from $100 to $300. This year we have been able to increase this benefit by a further $100 to a new maximum of $400. The Government has been concerned about the practice of some persons foregoing income in order to gain a Service pension, a higher rate of the Service pension or fringe benefits. The legislation is to be amended to allow the Repatriation Commission to deem such foregone income to be income for the purposes of the income test applying to Service pensions and fringe benefits. The period for which such income will be maintained as income will be determined by the Commission in accordance with the facts of each case.

Mr President, I am sure that the extension of eligibility and increases in benefits which have been announced tonight will be very welcome among those in the veteran community. In addition to these measures announced tonight, veterans and their dependants will benefit from the increases in the main repatriation pensions brought about by movements in the consumer price index over the six months to the end of June this year. These increases, which I announced on 30 July, will apply from the first payday in November.

I might mention that there has been some anxiety expressed that, with the apparent ending of indexation of salaries and wages by the Arbitration Commission, the indexation of repatriation pensions might cease. I would like to make it clear that this measure introduced by the Government in 1976 will continue.

The Government has had before it a number of proposals for capital expenditure at the repatriation hospitals, one of which had been considered by the Parliamentary Public Works Committee. It is not possible to announce a decision on any of these proposals, which involve the expenditure of many millions of dollars. The Government will be giving further consideration to repatriation hospitals later this year.

The Government is not able this year to make any changes to benefits under the Defence Service Homes Scheme, but honourable senators will be aware that last year the Government made a very generous increase in the maximum loan obtainable under this scheme from $15,000 to $25,000 maximum and the waiting period for finance to assist with the purchase of a new home or a previously occupied home was reduced from 14 months to 10 months. Also, Mr President, the interest rates on DSH loans have not been changed, so that in view of the very high rates now being charged by commercial lenders, those eligible for DSH loans, at an average of about 7 per cent interest on the maximum amount, are placed in a very favourable position.

Honourable senators will be aware of the Government's concern to assist veterans of the Vietnam war with their health and personal problems. To this end, I have already announced that an expanded counselling service will be established to help them at centres in each State capital city and in Darwin and, if necessary, to refer them to specialist services in the repatriation system or in the community. A sum of $625,000 has been approved to meet the operating expenses of this counselling service in the current financial year. I hope, Mr President, that these new measures which I have just outlined, will show the Government's genuine concern for those who have served their country in time of war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I am in the same situation as I was in with regard to the statement by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in that it is difficult for one with shadow responsibilities like mine to go through all the details of a statement. The interesting thing that will come out of the statement by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) is not that pensions and benefits in this area have been increased in line with inflation, therefore maintaining but not increasing their levels, as the Minister tried to imply in his statement. I refer to the statement which appears on page 2, which says:

Repatriation benefits are also to be extended to members of peacekeeping, observation and monitoring forces representing Australia under United Nations or other recognised international arrangements. This will apply to persons who served in such forces after 1 November this year.

Of course, I have no objection to that benefit being extended to those people. One wonders why it is done at this time. Quite clearly it is done in anticipation of the announcement of the decision, which has already been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), to involve Australian troops in a peacekeeping force in the Sinai this year. It is a sop relating to the statement which will be made by the Prime Minister shortly that we are to be unnecessarily involved in this military operation overseas.

I suggest it is absolutely typical of the Prime Minister of this country that, having wandered around making this promise to his friends across the Pacific and having made this known to his own colleagues in this country, he is unwilling to make a statement and to come clean with the Parliament and the people until he does a little preparatory work. The worst sort of preparatory work is to ask the junior Minister for Veterans' Affairs to wander into this place to slip into the middle of a statement on repatriation benefits this sop which obviously is aimed at what the Prime Minister intends to do. As a result of this statement the Prime Minister should present to both Houses of Parliament his plans on this matter. It is a pity that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs allowed himself to be used in this way and did not demand that the Prime Minister come clean with the people of this country, with this Parliament and even perhaps with the Minister himself.

We will examine the rest of the benefits, and the lack of benefits, in the Veterans' Affairs area as we do each year and make a considered statement later. I believe it is important that we point out another example of deception by the gentleman who, unfortunately for this country, is the Prime Minister at the moment. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Senate adjourned at 9.39 p.m.
